qas.question: Which country's air defence and aircraft has been under integrated command and control?
What other group has also been under this integrated command and control?
Who will deploy their own air defence if their is an air threat?
What can be deployed as an offensive measure to refuse airspace use to an opponent?

context: In some countries, such as Britain and Germany during the Second World War, the <a0_0>Soviet Union<a0_0/> and <a1_0>NATO's Allied Command Europe<a1_0/>, ground based air defence and air defence aircraft have been under integrated command and control. However, while overall air defence may be for homeland defence including military facilities, <a2_0>forces in the field<a2_0/>, wherever they are, invariably deploy their own air defence capability if there is an air threat. <a3_0>A surface-based air defence capability<a3_0/> can also be deployed offensively to deny the use of airspace to an opponent.
